testTitle: Life in the UK Test - 18th Century & Georgian Era
testDescription: Comprehensive test covering the Georgian period, Union with Scotland, Jacobite rebellions, agricultural and early industrial developments, and cultural changes.

questions.stem: In which year did England and Scotland unite to form Great Britain?
questions.explanation: The Act of Union in 1707 united England and Scotland into the Kingdom of Great Britain, creating a single Parliament in Westminster.

questions.stem: Who was the first Hanoverian king?
questions.explanation: George I became king in 1714, beginning the Hanoverian dynasty. He was German and spoke little English.

questions.stem: The Jacobites supported which royal line?
questions.explanation: The Jacobites supported the restoration of the Stuart line, particularly James II and his descendants, believing they were the rightful kings.

questions.stem: Bonnie Prince Charlie led the Jacobite rebellion of 1745.
questions.explanation: True. Charles Edward Stuart (Bonnie Prince Charlie) led the 1745 Jacobite rebellion, which ended in defeat at Culloden.

questions.stem: The Battle of Culloden took place in which year?
questions.explanation: The Battle of Culloden was fought on April 16, 1746, and was the final defeat of the Jacobite cause.

questions.stem: What was the result of the Battle of Culloden?
questions.explanation: Culloden ended the Jacobite cause and led to harsh suppression of Highland culture, including bans on tartan and bagpipes. Scotland remained part of Britain.

questions.stem: Who was Robert Walpole?
questions.explanation: Robert Walpole is considered Britain's first Prime Minister, serving from 1721-1742 under George I and George II.

questions.stem: The Agricultural Revolution occurred before the Industrial Revolution.
questions.explanation: True. The Agricultural Revolution of the 18th century increased food production and freed up labor, enabling the Industrial Revolution.

questions.stem: What were enclosures?
questions.explanation: Enclosures involved fencing common land and converting it to private ownership, which improved agricultural efficiency but displaced many peasants.

questions.stem: Which crops were part of the Agricultural Revolution?
questions.explanation: The Agricultural Revolution introduced new crops like turnips, clover, and potatoes, which improved nutrition and agricultural productivity. Rice was not grown in Britain.

questions.stem: Who wrote 'A Dictionary of the English Language'?
questions.explanation: Dr Samuel Johnson published his famous dictionary in 1755, which was the standard English dictionary for over 150 years.

questions.stem: The coffee house was an important social institution in 18th century London.
questions.explanation: True. Coffee houses were centers of social, political, and business life in 18th century London, often called 'penny universities.'

questions.stem: Which composer wrote 'The Messiah'?
questions.explanation: George Frideric Handel, a German composer who settled in London, wrote 'The Messiah' in 1741.

questions.stem: What was the South Sea Bubble?
questions.explanation: The South Sea Bubble (1720) was a financial speculation in the South Sea Company that collapsed, ruining many investors.

questions.stem: The War of Jenkins' Ear was fought against which country?
questions.explanation: The War of Jenkins' Ear (1739-1748) was fought between Britain and Spain, named after Captain Robert Jenkins who claimed the Spanish cut off his ear.

questions.stem: General Wolfe died at the Battle of Quebec.
questions.explanation: True. General James Wolfe died in 1759 at the Battle of Quebec (Plains of Abraham) during the Seven Years' War, but secured British victory.

questions.stem: Who was known as 'The Great Commoner'?
questions.explanation: William Pitt the Elder was known as 'The Great Commoner' for his popular policies and refusal of a title until late in life.

questions.stem: What was the name of Captain Cook's ship?
questions.explanation: Captain Cook's first voyage to the Pacific was on HMS Endeavour (1768-1771), during which he mapped New Zealand and eastern Australia.

questions.stem: The Methodist movement was founded by John Wesley.
questions.explanation: True. John Wesley founded the Methodist movement in the 1730s as a revival within the Church of England, emphasizing personal faith and social reform.

questions.stem: Which two political parties dominated 18th century politics?
questions.explanation: The Whigs and Tories were the two main political parties in 18th century Britain. Modern party names came later.

questions.stem: What were the main differences between Whigs and Tories?
questions.explanation: Whigs generally supported Parliamentary power and religious tolerance, while Tories favored royal authority and the established church.

questions.stem: The gin craze was a social problem in 18th century London.
questions.explanation: True. The gin craze (1720s-1750s) led to widespread alcoholism and social problems, immortalized in Hogarth's prints 'Beer Street and Gin Lane.'

questions.stem: Who painted 'Marriage A-la-Mode'?
questions.explanation: William Hogarth painted 'Marriage A-la-Mode' (1743), a series of satirical paintings criticizing arranged marriages among the upper classes.

questions.stem: The Foundling Hospital was established by Thomas Coram.
questions.explanation: True. Thomas Coram established the Foundling Hospital in 1739 to care for abandoned children, reflecting growing social concern for welfare.
